awd_titl_txt: SNM: Additive Nanomanufacturing of Integrated Systems for Customized Personal Health Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
In today's economy of planned obsolescence, most consumer electronics can only be customized at the software level. In contrast, hardware that is specific to the user is out of economic reach for the vast majority of the world's population. Therefore, one of the key manufacturing challenges of the 21st century is the sustainable, energy-efficient, and cost-effective customizable production of systems that are personalized to each individual. This need is especially acute in the medical arena, in which personalized health monitoring requires integrated systems that are customized to the unique physiological composition and the geometric form of the individual. This Scalable NanoManufacturing (SNM) research project explores the surface chemistry and physical processes needed to directly print three-dimensional integrated systems with nanoscale features, and strategies to monitor and assure quality control of the printed materials and structures. These techniques can be used to realize three-dimensional customized systems such as smart contact lenses, which would enable a paradigm shift in continuous and non-invasive health monitoring by integrating sensors that can detect chemical changes in the body with wireless communication and power to transmit data to the user. This research combines several disciplines including nanomanufacturing, modeling and simulation, process control, system integration, and in situ characterization. The societal impact of the work is through public education workshops, outreach programs, and a new university course on advanced nanomanufacturing.

Current nanomanufacturing research has focused on high-volume, high-throughput techniques to produce millions of identical parts, making it impossible to customize integrated systems at a deep hardware level. To address these challenges, the research team will explore a new methodology to directly print functional nanomaterials onto non-planar, flexible surfaces with unparalleled spatial resolution in three dimensions. The manufacturing platform combines spatial atomic layer deposition with electrohydrodynamic-jet printing, and incorporates in situ process monitoring and control. The research spans disciplines from molecular control of surface chemistry, to modeling coupled electro-chemo-mechanical processes that occur during printing on a curved or non-planar surface, to characterizing the impact of geometric tolerances on component performance. The additive nanomanufacturing platform enables integration of multiple functions including power, sensing, and logic into a smart contact lens that can interface with sensitive regions of the human body to monitor chemical/electrochemical changes at the cellular level. A fundamental understanding of the physical, chemical, thermal, and transport phenomena that guide the precision and accuracy of the manufacturing process will be the focus of the research, which will unveil the underlying scientific challenges to printing integrated systems at the nanoscale.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
• The project focused on addressing fundamental challenges in additive nanomanufacturing of functional materials and devices. Conventional lithography methods often require multiple complex processes in a cleanroom, and are typically limited to rigid substrates. To reduce fabrication complexity, there is interest in printing as an alternative method of nanopatterning. However, conventional 3-D printing techniques typically do not have capability to fabricate customizable patterns with sub-micron resolution. Additionally, printed electronic devices, such as thin-film transistors (TFTs) often suffer from low yield and quality, which limits device performance. To address these challenges, in this project, we have explored the combination of area-selective ALD (AS-ALD) with electrohydrodynamic jet (e-jet) printing, the development of an integrated spatial ALD (SALD) and e-jet printing system, and studying the influence of ALD process parameters on electrical performance of TFTs and surfaces with structural color.
  • We have fabricated an integrated SALD/e-jet system that enables mechatronic control of process parameters including stage speed, gap height, and parallel alignment. A showerhead depositor delivers precursor to the substrate surface while stepper motors and capacitive probes maintain gap size and parallel alignment with closed-loop feedback. Motorized nstages control the substrate velocity and positioning, and in situ monitoring of the gas flow rates and deposition temperatures enable deposition of different functional materials using SALD system. A COMSOL Multiphysics model was developed to understand the effects of the pressure, velocity, and concentration gradients of the precursor gas flow within the system geometry during SALD. Additionally, a high-fidelity model of the e-jet printing process was developed to quantify the impact of printed material parameters on the resulting jetting behavior. The capability to tune process parameters both physically and digitally allows for the unique ability to experimentally validate and parameterize the computational model to gain further insights into the integrated e-jet/SALD processes.
  • We demonstrated the use of e-jet to print polymers with < 1 um resolution with additive e-jet printing and < 10 nm resolution with subtractive (displacement-based) e-jet printing in the x- and y-coordinates, which can act as the inhibitors for ALD growth. During additive printing, polymer inhibitors were directly printed  to passivate the growth of ALD, whereas in subtractive printing, solvent inks were printed on polymer inhibitors to activate the growth of ALD by exposing underlying substrate. The ability to control the subtractive printing process was studied with respect to the jetting process parameters. A bottom-gate, top contact TFT device was made using AS-ALD and e-jet printing. Zinc-tin-oxide (ZTO) was deposited as a semiconductor using negative e-jet printing and aluminum-doped-zinc-oxide (AZO) was deposited as a contact using positive e-jet printing.
  • We studied three different ALD processes of ZTO which was then used to fabricate TFTs. The cycle ratios of ZnO to SnO2, oxidants, and temperatures were varied to study the elemental composition and the electrical performance of the deposited ZTO films.  We introduced a new hybrid thermal-plasma ALD process, which exhibited record-high mobility. Increasing the deposition temperature and performing post-deposition anneals led to an increased density of the ALD ZTO films, improving their electrical properties.
  • We also studied robustness to aging and bias stress for ZTO TFT devices with and without Al2O3 ALD passivation. We demonstrated that changes due to positive bias stress, which are dominated by interactions with ambient molecules, are greatly reduced by Al2O3 passivation layer. Furthermore, we explored in situ deposition of ZTO channel and Al2O3 gate dielectric layer using ALD without breaking vacuum which showed a steep subthreshold swing (SS) of 59.9 mV∙dec-1 near the room temperature Boltzmann limit. A low interface trap density was extracted from the measured SS value.
  • We systematically varied the cation composition and annealing temperatures of ZTO films using ALD and studied their process-structure relationships with synchrotron X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES). Measurements of the O K-edge, Sn M-edge, and Zn L-edges were analyzed with ab initio and machine learning modeling to understand the changes in geometric and electronic structures of the films. We were able to illustrate how multi-modal X-ray analysis, combined with first-principles modeling can improve our understanding of local structures in amorphous oxide semiconductors and enable rational design of ternary ALD films.
  • We demonstrated asymmetric metal-dielectric-metal (MDM) Fabry-Perot structures to form optical cavities. The ALD ZnO thickness was varied from 40 nm to 160 nm which exhibited a full color cycle, which agreed with the simulated spectra. 3-D printed metal figurines were "painted" using the MDM structure, and vibrant and uniform colors were observed across the microscopic porous topologies from metal 3-D printing. Furthermore, by using e-jet printing, we demonstrated patterning of structural color with sub-10 um resolution.
  • Throughout the project, we have engaged in a number of education and outreach activities, including: training of undergraduate and graduate students; enrichment of curriculum; dissemination to researchers in interdisciplinary fields, practicing engineers, and the public; publication in journals and presentation at national and international conferences.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2022
Modified by: Neil Dasgupta
por.por_txt_cntn:
The project focused on addressing fundamental challenges in additive nanomanufacturing of functional materials and devices. Conventional lithography methods often require multiple complex processes in a cleanroom, and are typically limited to rigid substrates. To reduce fabrication complexity, there is interest in printing as an alternative method of nanopatterning. However, conventional 3-D printing techniques typically do not have capability to fabricate customizable patterns with sub-micron resolution. Additionally, printed electronic devices, such as thin-film transistors (TFTs) often suffer from low yield and quality, which limits device performance. To address these challenges, in this project, we have explored the combination of area-selective ALD (AS-ALD) with electrohydrodynamic jet (e-jet) printing, the development of an integrated spatial ALD (SALD) and e-jet printing system, and studying the influence of ALD process parameters on electrical performance of TFTs and surfaces with structural color.
We have fabricated an integrated SALD/e-jet system that enables mechatronic control of process parameters including stage speed, gap height, and parallel alignment. A showerhead depositor delivers precursor to the substrate surface while stepper motors and capacitive probes maintain gap size and parallel alignment with closed-loop feedback. Motorized nstages control the substrate velocity and positioning, and in situ monitoring of the gas flow rates and deposition temperatures enable deposition of different functional materials using SALD system. A COMSOL Multiphysics model was developed to understand the effects of the pressure, velocity, and concentration gradients of the precursor gas flow within the system geometry during SALD. Additionally, a high-fidelity model of the e-jet printing process was developed to quantify the impact of printed material parameters on the resulting jetting behavior. The capability to tune process parameters both physically and digitally allows for the unique ability to experimentally validate and parameterize the computational model to gain further insights into the integrated e-jet/SALD processes.
We demonstrated the use of e-jet to print polymers with < 1 um resolution with additive e-jet printing and < 10 nm resolution with subtractive (displacement-based) e-jet printing in the x- and y-coordinates, which can act as the inhibitors for ALD growth. During additive printing, polymer inhibitors were directly printed  to passivate the growth of ALD, whereas in subtractive printing, solvent inks were printed on polymer inhibitors to activate the growth of ALD by exposing underlying substrate. The ability to control the subtractive printing process was studied with respect to the jetting process parameters. A bottom-gate, top contact TFT device was made using AS-ALD and e-jet printing. Zinc-tin-oxide (ZTO) was deposited as a semiconductor using negative e-jet printing and aluminum-doped-zinc-oxide (AZO) was deposited as a contact using positive e-jet printing.
We studied three different ALD processes of ZTO which was then used to fabricate TFTs. The cycle ratios of ZnO to SnO2, oxidants, and temperatures were varied to study the elemental composition and the electrical performance of the deposited ZTO films.  We introduced a new hybrid thermal-plasma ALD process, which exhibited record-high mobility. Increasing the deposition temperature and performing post-deposition anneals led to an increased density of the ALD ZTO films, improving their electrical properties.
We also studied robustness to aging and bias stress for ZTO TFT devices with and without Al2O3 ALD passivation. We demonstrated that changes due to positive bias stress, which are dominated by interactions with ambient molecules, are greatly reduced by Al2O3 passivation layer. Furthermore, we explored in situ deposition of ZTO channel and Al2O3 gate dielectric layer using ALD without breaking vacuum which showed a steep subthreshold swing (SS) of 59.9 mV∙dec-1 near the room temperature Boltzmann limit. A low interface trap density was extracted from the measured SS value.
We systematically varied the cation composition and annealing temperatures of ZTO films using ALD and studied their process-structure relationships with synchrotron X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES). Measurements of the O K-edge, Sn M-edge, and Zn L-edges were analyzed with ab initio and machine learning modeling to understand the changes in geometric and electronic structures of the films. We were able to illustrate how multi-modal X-ray analysis, combined with first-principles modeling can improve our understanding of local structures in amorphous oxide semiconductors and enable rational design of ternary ALD films.
We demonstrated asymmetric metal-dielectric-metal (MDM) Fabry-Perot structures to form optical cavities. The ALD ZnO thickness was varied from 40 nm to 160 nm which exhibited a full color cycle, which agreed with the simulated spectra. 3-D printed metal figurines were "painted" using the MDM structure, and vibrant and uniform colors were observed across the microscopic porous topologies from metal 3-D printing. Furthermore, by using e-jet printing, we demonstrated patterning of structural color with sub-10 um resolution.
Throughout the project, we have engaged in a number of education and outreach activities, including: training of undergraduate and graduate students; enrichment of curriculum; dissemination to researchers in interdisciplinary fields, practicing engineers, and the public; publication in journals and presentation at national and international conferences.
